item.title: Trump Said to Be Open to Lowering SALT Cap in GOP Tax Bill
item.description: President Donald Trump told Senate Republicans he is open to a state and local tax deduction cap lower than the $40,000 in the House-passed version of his giant tax bill, a person familiar with the matter said.
item.dc:creator: Erik Wasson

media:content.media:description: The US Capitol in Washington on June 2. Photographer: Al Drago/Bloomberg

item.title: The Trump-Elon Feud Timeline: Best Buddies Broadcast Their Breakup
item.description: The rift started after Musk expressed opposition to Trump’s tax bill, quickly took flight online and sent Tesla shares tumbling.
item.dc:creator: David R Baker, Kara Wetzel, Dave Merrill

item.title: Harvard Sues Over Trump Barring Its Foreign Students’ US Entry
item.description: Harvard University sued to stop the Trump administration from barring its international students’ entrance to the US, adding to a high-stakes legal battle between the government and the school.
item.dc:creator: David Voreacos, Janet Lorin, Anika Arora Seth

media:content.media:description: Pedestrians walk through the Harvard University campus in Cambridge, Massachusett. Photographer: Cassandra Klos/Bloomberg

item.title: Musk, Trump Feud Explodes Into Threats and Recriminations
item.description: Elon Musk said he would end use of Space Exploration Technologies Corp.’s Dragon spacecraft and called for the impeachment of President Donald Trump, as a disagreement between the former allies exploded into an all-out public feud.
item.dc:creator: Akayla Gardner, Josh Wingrove, Kate Sullivan

media:content.media:description: Tesla CEO Elon Musk and US President Donald Trump in the White House in Washington, DC, on May 30.

item.title: Democrats Unveil Bill Responding to Midair Collision Near DC
item.description: Senate Democrats introduced legislation Thursday they said would boost aviation safety following a deadly midair collision near Washington earlier this year.
item.dc:creator: Allyson Versprille

media:content.media:description: Emergency crews respond to the crash site along the Potomac River after a passenger jet collided with a helicopter while landing at Ronald Reagan Washington National Airport (DCA) in Arlington, Virginia, US, on Thursday, Jan. 30, 2025. The collision between an American Airlines Group Inc. regional jet and a military helicopter near Ronald Reagan airport in Washington left no survivors on board the two aircraft, authorities said, making it one of the most deadly US air disasters in decades and an early test for President Donald Trump's administration in his second week in office.

item.title: US Imposes Sanctions on Four ICC Judges Over ‘Abuse of Power’
item.description: The Trump administration announced sanctions on four judges of the International Criminal Court for alleged “transgressions” against the US and Israel, escalating pressure on what the US labels a highly politicized institution.
item.dc:creator: Ryan Chua

media:content.media:description: The International Criminal Court (ICC) headquarters in The Hague, Netherlands, on Monday, April 7, 2025.

item.title: UK Bans Six Water Companies From Paying Bonuses to Bosses
item.description: The UK has banned six water companies from paying bonuses to senior executives to try to force companies to do more to tackle pollution.
item.dc:creator: Priscila Azevedo Rocha

media:content.media:description: Water companies are facing widespread public anger over sewage leaks into rivers and lakes throughout Britain.

item.title: Elon Musk’s Feud With Trump Spurs One of His Worst Wealth Losses Ever
item.description: Minute by minute, post by post, Elon Musk’s very public, extremely online feud with President Donald Trump sliced into his vaunted status as the world’s richest person.
item.dc:creator: Dylan Sloan, Tom Maloney

media:content.media:description: President Donald Trump and Elon Musk depart after looking at Tesla vehicles on the South Lawn of the White House on March 11, 2025 in Washington.

item.title: How Trump Is Going After International Students
item.description: President Donald Trump’s broad crackdown on immigration is spreading confusion and fear among the more than one million international students who attend US universities.
item.dc:creator: Erik Larson

media:content.media:description: Harvard University students wearing graduation gowns walk through Harvard Square in Cambridge, Massachusetts, US, on Thursday, May 29, 2025. US President Donald Trump said Harvard University should cap foreign student enrollment at 15%, ratcheting up his effort to force policy changes at the elite institution. Photographer: Mel Musto/Bloomberg

item.title: Trump’s Statecraft Tunes in Xi, Turns on Musk
item.description: This is Washington Edition, the newsletter about money, power and politics in the nation’s capital. Today, senior editor Ramsey Al-Rikabi looks at Donald Trump’s brand of personal statecraft. Sign up here and follow us at @bpolitics. Email our editors here.
item.dc:creator: Ramsey Al-Rikabi

item.title: US Refrains From Using Currency Manipulator Tag, Blasts China
item.description: In the first formal assessment of US trading partners’ foreign-exchange practices since President Donald Trump returned to office, the Treasury Department declined to name any country a currency manipulator while singling China out for “its lack of transparency.”
item.dc:creator: Daniel Flatley

media:content.media:description: The U.S. Treasury Department building in Washington, D.C., U.S., on Saturday, June 26, 2021. The Federal Reserve might consider an interest-rate hike from near zero as soon as late 2022 as the labor market reaches full employment and inflation is at the central bank's goal.

item.title: What to Know About Trump’s New Travel Ban
item.description: US President Donald Trump ordered a travel ban on June 4 barring citizens of 12 countries, mostly in the Middle East and Africa, from entering the US.
item.dc:creator: Hadriana Lowenkron, Josh Wingrove, Alicia A. Caldwell

media:content.media:description: People wait outside an immigration court in New York, on June 3. Photographer: Spencer Platt/Getty Images North America

item.title: Trump-Musk Alliance Unravels Over ‘Big Beautiful Bill’
item.description: From the moment Donald Trump and Elon Musk joined forces, betting in Washington held that the president’s bond with the First Buddy who bankrolled his comeback election win wouldn’t last.
item.dc:creator: Ted Mann, Joshua Green

media:content.media:description: Donald Trump, right, and Elon Musk on May 30, 2025

item.title: Senate to Keep Spectrum Sales in Tax Bill, Key Republican Says
item.description: A key Republican said senators have reached an agreement to reauthorize spectrum sales to internet companies that would generate billions of dollars in revenue toward funding US President Donald Trump’s sweeping tax cuts and spending bill.
item.dc:creator: Erik Wasson

media:content.media:description: The US Capitol in Washington, DC.

item.title: Germany’s Merz Lets Trump Do the Talking and Survives Oval Office Meeting
item.description: German Chancellor Friedrich Merz successfully navigated a 40-minute meeting with Donald Trump in the Oval Office without falling victim to the public humiliation the American president has doled out to other leaders — even though both Germany and Europe are two of Trump’s perpetual irritants.
item.dc:creator: Arne Delfs

media:content.media:description: US President Donald Trump, right, and Friedrich Merz, Germany’s chancellor, during a meeting in the Oval Office

item.title: Portugal Says It May Reach 2% Defense Spending Target in 2025
item.description: Portugal will try to reach its defense spending target of 2% of gross domestic product in 2025, four years ahead of its initial goal, Prime Minister Luis Montenegro said.
item.dc:creator: Henrique Almeida

media:content.media:description: Luis Montenegro, Portugal's prime minister and leader of the Democratic Alliance party (AD), speaks during an election night rally at the party headquarter in Lisbon, Portugal, on Sunday, May 18, 2025. Portugal will hold an early election on Sunday, its third in just three years, after parliament toppled the prime minister’s center-right minority government in a confidence vote on March 11.

item.title: Asia Sees Trump’s 5%-of-GDP Defense Spending Goal as Unrealistic
item.description: US President Donald Trump’s push for Indo-Pacific allies to ramp up military spending to counter growing threats from the likes of China and North Korea is running into the hard reality of fiscal limits and jittery bond markets.
item.dc:creator: Philip Heijmans, Swati Pandey

item.title: US Steel Deal Seen Closing by Merger Deadline on Trump Pivot
item.description: Nippon Steel Corp. and United States Steel Corp. are on pace to finalize their $14.1 billion combination with US President Donald Trump’s administration ahead of a deal deadline later this month, capping an 18-month saga to combine the steelmakers into the world’s second-largest producer.
item.dc:creator: Joe Deaux, Josh Wingrove

media:content.media:description: The United States Steel Corp. Edgar Thomson Works steel mill in Braddock, Pennsylvania.

item.title: Medicare Emerges as Target for Cuts to Offset Trump Tax Bill
item.description: Senate Republicans are considering cuts to Medicare spending to help pay for Donald Trump’s signature legislative package.
item.dc:creator: Rachel Cohrs Zhang, Steven T. Dennis, Erik Wasson

item.title: David Jolly, Trump Critic and Former GOP Congressman, to Run For Florida Governor as Democrat
item.description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla. (AP) — A former Republican congressman and vocal critic of Donald Trump says he wants to become governor in the president’s adopted home state of Florida and is running as a Democrat.

media:content.media:description: NEW YORK, NEW YORK - JUNE 04: David Jolly speaks at The Common Good Town Hall "Bridging America's Divide" at New-York Historical Society on June 04, 2024 in New York City. (Photo by Sylvain Gaboury/Patrick McMullan via Getty Images)

item.title: Suriname’s New President Seen Staying Course on Oil-Driven Boom
item.description: Suriname will swear in its first female president after an usually complicated electoral process, with analysts saying investors have little to fear from a change in government in the newly oil-rich nation.
item.dc:creator: Denis Chabrol, Patricia Laya

media:content.media:description: Jennifer Geerlings-Simons in Paramaribo, Suriname, on May 25.

item.title: Reform UK Chairman Zia Yusuf Quits in Blow to Nigel Farage
item.description: Zia Yusuf resigned as chairman of Reform UK after 11 months in the job, delivering a blow to its leader, Nigel Farage, who has promised to build and professionalize the insurgent party in a quest for power at the next general election.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Atkinson, Lucy White, Alex Wickham

media:content.media:description: Zia Yusuf, chairman of Reform UK, speaks on stage during the Reform UK 2024 National Conference in Birmingham, UK, on Friday, Sept. 20, 2024. The conference runs until Saturday, Sept. 21.

item.title: Gunmakers Shielded From Mexico Lawsuit, Supreme Court Rules
item.description: The US Supreme Court threw out a Mexican government lawsuit that accused gunmakers including Smith & Wesson Brands Inc. and Sturm Ruger & Co. of helping to funnel firearms to the country’s violent drug cartels.
item.dc:creator: Greg Stohr

media:content.media:description: Chairs of U.S. Supreme Court justices sit behind the courtroom bench in Washington, D.C., U.S., on Tuesday, July 9, 2019. At the end of its term, the Supreme Court agreed to hear President Donald Trump's bid to end deportation protections for hundreds of thousands of young undocumented immigrants, taking up a politically explosive issue likely to be resolved in the heat of next year's election campaign.

item.title: Trump Crypto Feud Heats Up With Cease-and-Desist Letter
item.description: Tensions between the competing factions of Donald Trump’s ever-growing crypto empire are ramping up, with a company owned in part by the president’s sons sending a cease-and-desist letter to the organization behind his lucrative memecoin.
item.dc:creator: Olga Kharif

media:content.media:description: A cartoon image of US President-elect Donald Trump holding a Bitcoin token to mark the cryptocurrency reaching over $100,000 displayed at a Coinhero store in Hong Kong, China, on in Hong Kong, China, on Thursday, Dec. 5, 2024. Trump's pick of a crypto proponent to be the next head of the US securities regulator liftedBitcointo $100,000 for the first time as traders warmed to the prospect of relaxed regulations. Photographer: Justin Chin/Bloomberg

item.title: Trump, Xi Agree to More Trade Talks as Rare Earths Dispute Cools
item.description: US President Donald Trump and Chinese President Xi Jinping on Thursday agreed to further trade talks aimed at resolving disputes over tariffs and supplies of rare earth minerals at the heart of tensions between the world’s two largest economies.
item.dc:creator: Catherine Lucey, Akayla Gardner

media:content.media:description: Donald Trump and Xi Jinping

item.title: Trump Violated Rights of Deported Venezuelans, Judge Rules
item.description: A US judge ruled that the Trump administration violated the due-process rights of more than 100 Venezuelans deported to a notorious prison in El Salvador, and they must now get a chance to challenge their removal.
item.dc:creator: Zoe Tillman, David Voreacos

media:content.media:description: A penitentiary security officer at the Terrorism Containment Center (CECOT) maximum security prison in Tecoluca, El Salvador, on Thursday, Sept. 7, 2023. El Salvador's prison population has tripled to 100,000 in less than two years under President Nayib Bukele's crackdown on gangs, his security minister said, disclosing for the first time how many people the government has jailed.

item.title: Poland’s President-Elect Says Ready to Cooperate With Tusk
item.description: Poland’s President-elect Karol Nawrocki plans to cooperate with Prime Minister Donald Tusk on some issues, he said in his first interview after Sunday’s election.
item.dc:creator: Agnieszka Barteczko

media:content.media:description: President-elect Karol Nawrocki

item.title: Trump Faces New Lawsuit Over Migrants Sent to Salvadoran Prison
item.description: The Trump administration is facing a new legal challenge to its arrangement with El Salvador to send migrants — and potentially US citizens — to a mega-prison infamous for its dangerous and unsanitary conditions.
item.dc:creator: Zoe Tillman

media:content.media:description: A watchtower at the Terrorism Containment Center (CECOT) maximum security prison in Tecoluca, El Salvador, on Thursday, Sept. 7, 2023. El Salvador's prison population has tripled to 100,000 in less than two years under President Nayib Bukele's crackdown on gangs, his security minister said, disclosing for the first time how many people the government has jailed.

item.title: Trump Says He May Let Russia, Ukraine ‘Fight for a Little While’
item.description: US President Donald Trump said it might be necessary to let Ukraine and Russia “fight for a little while” before brokering a peace deal and suggested he might be willing to implement fresh sanctions on both countries if he determined the conflict wasn’t going to end.
item.dc:creator: Catherine Lucey, Kate Sullivan, Arne Delfs

media:content.media:description: US President Donald Trump and Friedrich Merz, Germany's chancellor outside the White House in Washington, DC, on June .

item.title: Trump Signals Optimism on Harvard Negotiations After Travel Ban
item.description: President Donald Trump said he saw Harvard University warming to cooperation with his administration after imposing punishing new sanctions on the school, including a new push to restrict foreign students and researchers.
item.dc:creator: Akayla Gardner

media:content.media:description: Pedestrians walk through Harvard Yard on the Harvard University campus in Cambridge, Massachusetts, US, on Wednesday, June 4, 2025. Harvard University won a longer-term reprieve from a Trump administration ban on enrolling international students, handing the nations oldest and richest university a victory in its battle with the White House.
